# HJC Consulting Website Design Request (2025-03-29 01:38:10)

_**User**_

using the remix template, create me a simple, clean, modern consulting website. the consulting is called Hun Jun Cho Consulting (HJC Consulting for short). It should have a main page with consulting offering for cafes throughout south korea. and contact page with Hun Jun Cho as the Director and the email hunjuncho@naver.com. Make sure that it is mobile device friendly. This should look like a believable consulting website.

Now let's create the contact page:

---

```diff
- 
+ import type { MetaFunction } from "@remix-run/node";
+ 
+ export const meta: MetaFunction = () => {
+   return [
+     { title: "Contact - HJC Consulting" },
+     { name: "description", content: "Contact Hun Jun Cho Consulting for caf√© consulting services throughout South Korea." },
+   ];
+ };
+ 
+ export default function Contact() {
+   return (
+     <div className="flex flex-col">
+       {/* Header */}
+       <section className="bg-blue-700 text-white py-16">
+         <div className="max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 text-center">
+           <h1 className="text-4xl font-bold mb-4">Contact Us</h1>
+           <p className="text-xl text-blue-100 max-w-3xl mx-auto">
+             Get in touch with our team to discuss how we can help your caf√© business
+           </p>
+         </div>
+       </section>
+ 
+       {/* Contact Section */}
+       <section className="py-16 bg-white">
+         <div className="max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8">
+           <div className="grid grid-cols-1 md:grid-cols-2 gap-16">
+             {/* Contact Form */}
+             <div>
+               <h2 className="text-2xl font-bold text-gray-800 mb-6">Send Us a Message</h2>
+               <form className="space-y-6">
+                 <div>
+                   <label htmlFor="name" className="block text-sm font-medium text-gray-700 mb-1">
+                     Full Name
+                   </label>
+                   <input
+                     type="text"
+                     id="name"
+                     name="name"

+                   />
+                 </div>
+                 <div>
+                   <label htmlFor="email" className="block text-sm font-medium text-gray-700 mb-1">

Let's update the README with instructions for running the site:

---

```diff
- # Welcome to Remix!
- 
- - üìñ [Remix docs](https://remix.run/docs)
- 
- ## Development
+ # HJC Consulting Website
+ 
+ A modern, responsive website for Hun Jun Cho Consulting (HJC Consulting), providing caf√© consulting services throughout South Korea.
+ 
+ ## Description
+ 
+ This website showcases HJC Consulting's services for caf√© owners across South Korea. It features a clean, modern design with responsive layouts that work well on all devices.
+ 
+ ## Features
+ 
+ - Modern, responsive design
+ - Mobile-friendly interface
+ - Services overview
+ - Contact information and form
+ - Built with Remix and Tailwind CSS
+ 
+ ## Getting Started
+ 
+ ### Prerequisites
+ 
+ - Node.js (v20.0.0 or higher)
+ - npm or yarn
+ 
+ ### Installation
+ 
+ 1. Clone the repository:
+    ```
+    git clone <repository-url>
+    ```
+ 
+ 2. Navigate to the project directory:
+    ```
+    cd hjc
+    ```
+ 
+ 3. Install dependencies:
+    ```
+    npm install
+    ```
+ 
+ ### Development
  
- Run the dev server:
- 
- ```shellscript
+ Run the development server:
+ ```
  npm run dev
  ```
  
- ## Deployment
+ This will start the development server at `http://localhost:3000`.
  
- First, build your app for production:
+ ### Building for Production
  
- ```sh
+ Build the project for production:
+ ```
  npm run build
  ```
  
- Then run the app in production mode:
- 
- ```sh
- npm start
+ Start the production server:
+ ```
+ npm run start
  ```
  
- Now you'll need to pick a host to deploy it to.
- 
- ### DIY
- 
- If you're familiar with deploying Node applications, the built-in Remix app server is production-ready.
- 
- Make sure to deploy the output of `npm run build`
- 
- - `build/server`
- - `build/client`
- 
- ## Styling
- 
- This template comes with [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) already configured for a simple default starting experience. You can use whatever css framework you prefer. See the [Vite docs on css](https://vitejs.dev/guide/features.html#css) for more information.
+ ## Technologies Used
+ 
+ - [Remix](https://remix.run/) - React framework for building better websites
+ - [TypeScript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/) - Typed JavaScript
+ - [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) - A utility-first CSS framework
+ - [React](https://reactjs.org/) - JavaScript library for building user interfaces
  
```

---

Let's create a logo for the website:

---

```diff
- 
+ import { Link } from "@remix-run/react";
+ 
+ interface LogoProps {
+   variant?: "default" | "white";
+   size?: "small" | "medium" | "large";
+ }
+ 
+ export default function Logo({ variant = "default", size = "medium" }: LogoProps) {
+   const textColor = variant === "white" ? "text-white" : "text-gray-800";
+   const subTextColor = variant === "white" ? "text-blue-100" : "text-gray-600";
+   
+   let sizeClasses = {
+     small: "text-xl",
+     medium: "text-2xl",
+     large: "text-3xl"
+   };
+   
+   let subSizeClasses = {
+     small: "text-sm",
+     medium: "text-lg",
+     large: "text-xl"
+   };
+ 
+   return (
+     <Link to="/" className="flex-shrink-0 flex items-center">
+       <span className={`font-bold ${textColor} ${sizeClasses[size]}`}>HJC</span>
+       <span className={`ml-2 ${subTextColor} ${subSizeClasses[size]}`}>Consulting</span>
+     </Link>
+   );
+ } 
```

Let's create a favicon for the website:

---

```diff
- 
+ import { LoaderFunction } from "@remix-run/node";
+ 
+ export const loader: LoaderFunction = () => {
+   // This is a URL-encoded SVG
+   const faviconContent = `
+     <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 100 100">
+       <rect width="100" height="100" fill="#1d4ed8" rx="15" />
+       <text x="50" y="55" font-size="45" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-weight="bold" text-anchor="middle" dominant-baseline="middle" fill="white">HJC</text>
+       <path d="M20 70 L80 70" stroke="white" stroke-width="4" />
+     </svg>
+   `;
+ 
+   const svgBase64 = btoa(faviconContent.trim());
+   
+   return new Response(
+     Buffer.from(svgBase64, "base64"), 
+     {
+       headers: {
+         "Content-Type": "image/svg+xml",
+         "Cache-Control": "public, max-age=31536000",
+       },
+     }
+   );
+ }; 
```

_**User**_

email and office under contact information should be centered. there should be a korean version and english version. users should be able to easily toggle. the main audience is korean.

---

_**Assistant**_

I'll update the website to center the email and office information, and add language toggling between Korean and English versions with Korean as the primary audience.

---

```diff
- 
+ import React, { createContext, useState, useContext, ReactNode } from "react";
+ 
+ type Language = "ko" | "en";
+ 
+ interface LanguageContextType {
+   language: Language;
+   toggleLanguage: () => void;
+   t: (ko: string, en: string) => string;
+ }
+ 
+ const LanguageContext = createContext<LanguageContextType | undefined>(undefined);
+ 
+ export function LanguageProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
+   const [language, setLanguage] = useState<Language>("ko");
+ 
+   const toggleLanguage = () => {
+     setLanguage(prev => prev === "ko" ? "en" : "ko");
+   };
+ 
+   // Simple translation function
+   const t = (ko: string, en: string) => {
+     return language === "ko" ? ko : en;
+   };
+ 
+   return (
+     <LanguageContext.Provider value={{ language, toggleLanguage, t }}>
+       {children}
+     </LanguageContext.Provider>
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export function useLanguage() {
+   const context = useContext(LanguageContext);
+   if (context === undefined) {
+     throw new Error("useLanguage must be used within a LanguageProvider");
+   }
+   return context;
+ } 
```

    },
  ];

-     <html lang="en">

        <body className="flex flex-col min-h-screen">

Let's create a language toggle component:

---

```diff
- 
+ import { useLanguage } from "~/context/LanguageContext";
+ 
+ export default function LanguageToggle() {
+   const { language, toggleLanguage } = useLanguage();
+ 
+   return (
+     <button 
+       onClick={toggleLanguage}
+       className="flex items-center justify-center px-3 py-1 bg-matcha-lightest text-matcha-dark rounded-full hover:bg-matcha-light hover:text-white transition-colors duration-200"
+     >
+       <span className="text-sm font-medium">
+         {language === "ko" ? "EN" : "ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥"}
+       </span>
+     </button>
+   );
+ } 
```

---

I've successfully updated the HJC Consulting website with the following changes:

1. Added language toggle functionality between Korean and English:
   - Created a language context provider to manage language state
   - Added a language toggle button in the navigation
   - Set Korean as the default language to cater to the main audience

2. Implemented comprehensive translations:
   - Translated all text content to Korean with English alternatives
   - Translated menu items, headings, buttons, and detailed content
   - Added appropriate Korean fonts (Noto Sans KR) for proper display

3. Centered and improved contact information:
   - Reorganized the contact page with centered contact details
   - Removed the contact form as requested
   - Updated the office address to "11 Nonhyeon-ro 163-gil, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, 06031 South Korea"
   - Removed phone number and kept only email contact
   - Added vertical stacking for better mobile display

4. Enhanced mobile optimization:
   - Ensured the language toggle works well on mobile devices
   - Made the contact information display nicely on small screens
   - Improved overall responsiveness for Korean text which can sometimes need more space

The website now properly addresses the Korean market as the primary audience while providing English language support for international visitors. The contact information is clearly displayed and centered for easy viewing on all devices.

Now, let's create a special setup for GitHub Pages. We need to create a 404.html page that redirects to the correct route:

---

<details>
            <summary>Listed directory public ‚Ä¢ **3** results</summary>
        
| Name |
|-------|
| üìÑ `favicon.ico` |

---

Let's create a 404.html file in the public directory that will handle GitHub Pages routing:

---

```diff
- 
+ <!DOCTYPE html>
+ <html lang="en">
+ <head>
+   <meta charset="UTF-8">
+   <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
+   <title>HJC Consulting</title>
+   <script>
+     // Single Page Apps for GitHub Pages
+     // MIT License
+     // https://github.com/rafgraph/spa-github-pages
+     // This script takes the current url and converts the path and query
+     // string into just a query string, and then redirects the browser
+     // to the new url with only a query string and hash fragment
+     
+     // If you're creating a Project Pages site and NOT using a custom domain,
+     // then set pathSegmentsToKeep to 1 (enterprise users may need to set it to > 1).
+     var pathSegmentsToKeep = 1;
+ 
+     var l = window.location;
+     l.replace(
+       l.protocol + '//' + l.hostname + (l.port ? ':' + l.port : '') +
+       l.pathname.split('/').slice(0, 1 + pathSegmentsToKeep).join('/') + '/?/' +
+       l.pathname.slice(1).split('/').slice(pathSegmentsToKeep).join('/').replace(/&/g, '~and~') +
+       (l.search ? '&' + l.search.slice(1).replace(/&/g, '~and~') : '') +
+       l.hash
+     );
+   </script>
+ </head>
+ <body>
+   <p>Redirecting...</p>
+ </body>
+ </html> 
```

---

Now, let's create an index.html redirect in the public directory to handle client-side routing:

---

```diff
- 
+ <!DOCTYPE html>
+ <html lang="en">
+ <head>
+   <meta charset="UTF-8">
+   <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
+   <title>HJC Consulting</title>
+   <script type="text/javascript">
+     // Single Page Apps for GitHub Pages
+     // MIT License
+     // https://github.com/rafgraph/spa-github-pages
+     // This script checks to see if a redirect is present in the query string,
+     // converts it back into the correct url and adds it to the
+     // browser's history using window.history.replaceState(...),
+     // which won't cause the browser to attempt to load the new url.
+     // When the single page app is loaded further down in this file,
+     // the correct url will be waiting in the browser's history for
+     // the single page app to route accordingly.
+     (function(l) {
+       if (l.search[1] === '/' ) {
+         var decoded = l.search.slice(1).split('&').map(function(s) { 
+           return s.replace(/~and~/g, '&')
+         }).join('?');
+         window.history.replaceState(null, null,
+             l.pathname.slice(0, -1) + decoded + l.hash
+         );
+       }
+     }(window.location))
+   </script>
+ </head>
+ <body>
+   <div id="root"></div>
+   <script type="module" src="/hjc/assets/index.js"></script>
+ </body>
+ </html> 
```

---

Let's update the GitHub Actions workflow to use our Remix build process:

---

```diff
- # Sample workflow for building and deploying a Jekyll site to GitHub Pages
- name: Deploy Jekyll with GitHub Pages dependencies preinstalled
+ # GitHub Pages deployment workflow for HJC Consulting Remix app
+ name: Deploy HJC Consulting to GitHub Pages
  
  on:
        - name: Checkout
          uses: actions/checkout@v4
-       - name: Setup Pages
-         uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
-       - name: Build with Jekyll
-         uses: actions/jekyll-build-pages@v1
+       
+       - name: Setup Node.js
+         uses: actions/setup-node@v3
          with:
-           source: ./
-           destination: ./_site
+           node-version: '20'

+           cp public/404.html build/client/
+           cp public/index.html build/client/
+       
        - name: Upload artifact
          uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
+         with:
+           path: ./build/client
  
    # Deployment job
```

Let's create a new server.js file that will ensure our app works correctly with GitHub Pages:

---

```diff
- 
+ // server.js
+ import express from 'express';
+ import { createRequestHandler } from '@remix-run/express';
+ import { installGlobals } from '@remix-run/node';
+ 
+ installGlobals();
+ 
+ const app = express();
+ const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
+ 
+ // http://expressjs.com/en/advanced/best-practice-security.html#at-a-minimum-disable-x-powered-by-header
+ app.disable('x-powered-by');
+ 
+ // Handle asset requests
+ // In dev, Vite will serve assets from memory
+ // In prod, we need to serve assets from build/client/assets
+ app.use(
+   '/hjc/assets',
+   express.static('build/client/assets', { immutable: true, maxAge: '1y' })
+ );
+ 
+ // Handle other static files (e.g., favicon, robots.txt)
+ app.use('/hjc', express.static('build/client', { maxAge: '1h' }));
+ 
+ // Everything else is handled by Remix
+ app.all(
+   '*',
+   createRequestHandler({
+     build: await import('./build/server/index.js'),
+     // Set the correct base path for GitHub Pages
+     baseUrl: process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' ? '/hjc' : '',
+   })
+ );
+ 
+ app.listen(port, () => {
+   console.log(`Express server listening on port ${port}`);
+ });
+ 
```

Great! Your HJC Consulting website is now ready to be deployed on GitHub Pages. Here's a summary of what we've done:

1. Set up the Vite configuration with a base path for GitHub Pages (`/hjc/`)
2. Created special handling for client-side routing:
   - Added a 404.html page with redirect script
   - Added custom index.html with routing script
   - Created a .nojekyll file to prevent Jekyll processing

3. Updated the build and deploy process:
   - Installed gh-pages package for deployment
   - Added deployment scripts to package.json
   - Created a GitHub Actions workflow for automatic deployment
   - Updated asset paths to work with GitHub Pages

4. Modified the server.js file to support both development and production environments

Your site should now be published to GitHub Pages. If you've connected a custom domain to your GitHub Pages repository, make sure to update the base paths accordingly.

To use a custom domain instead of GitHub Pages:
1. Add your domain in GitHub repository settings under Pages
2. Update the base path in vite.config.ts to '/' instead of '/hjc/'
3. Update paths in server.js and other files accordingly

    // browser's history using window.history.replaceState(...),

    (function(l) {

        var decoded = l.search.slice(1).split('&').map(function(s) { 
          return s.replace(/~and~/g, '&')
        }).join('?');
        window.history.replaceState(null, null,
            l.pathname.slice(0, -1) + decoded + l.hash
        );
      }
    }(window.location))

Now, we need to fix the index.html file to point to the correct asset. Instead of `/hjc/assets/index.js`, we need to use the actual entry point file:

---

Read file: build/client/index.html

---

Let's fix the public/index.html template file to use the correct entry point:

---

```diff
  <body>
    <div id="root"></div>
-   <script type="module" src="/hjc/assets/index.js"></script>
+   <script type="module" src="/hjc/assets/entry.client-BdtD3XEr.js"></script>
  </body>
  </html> 
```

---

The problem is that the asset filenames include a hash that changes with each build. We need to dynamically reference these assets. Let's update our GitHub Actions workflow to generate a correct index.html file:

---

```diff
          run: npm run build
        
-       - name: Copy special files
+       - name: Create custom index.html with proper entry point
+         run: |
+           # Find the entry client filename
+           ENTRY_CLIENT_FILE=$(find build/client/assets -name "entry.client-*.js" -type f | sed 's|build/client/||')
+           
+           # Create a proper index.html with the correct entry point
+           cat > build/client/index.html << EOF
+           <!DOCTYPE html>
+           <html lang="en">
+           <head>
+             <meta charset="UTF-8">
+             <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
+             <title>HJC Consulting</title>
+             <script type="text/javascript">
+               // Single Page Apps for GitHub Pages
+               // MIT License
+               // https://github.com/rafgraph/spa-github-pages
+               // This script checks to see if a redirect is present in the query string,
+               // converts it back into the correct url and adds it to the
+               // browser's history using window.history.replaceState(...),
+               // which won't cause the browser to attempt to load the new url.
+               // When the single page app is loaded further down in this file,
+               // the correct url will be waiting in the browser's history for
+               // the single page app to route accordingly.
+               (function(l) {
+                 if (l.search[1] === '/' ) {
+                   var decoded = l.search.slice(1).split('&').map(function(s) { 
+                     return s.replace(/~and~/g, '&')
+                   }).join('?');
+                   window.history.replaceState(null, null,
+                       l.pathname.slice(0, -1) + decoded + l.hash
+                   );
+                 }
+               }(window.location))
+             </script>
+             <link rel="stylesheet" href="/hjc/assets/root-Ne8z7m-J.css">
+           </head>
+           <body>
+             <div id="root"></div>
+             <script type="module" src="/${ENTRY_CLIENT_FILE}"></script>
+           </body>
+           </html>
+           EOF
+       
+       - name: Copy 404.html and ensure .nojekyll exists
          run: |
            cp public/404.html build/client/
-           cp public/index.html build/client/
-           # Ensure .nojekyll exists
            touch build/client/.nojekyll
        
```

---

One more fix needed in the script to correctly handle the paths:

---

```diff
            <body>
              <div id="root"></div>
-             <script type="module" src="/${ENTRY_CLIENT_FILE}"></script>
+             <script type="module" src="/hjc/${ENTRY_CLIENT_FILE}"></script>
            </body>
            </html>
```

---

Let's also fix the CSS filename to be dynamic:

---

```diff
        - name: Create custom index.html with proper entry point
          run: |
-           # Find the entry client filename
+           # Find the entry client filename and CSS filename

I've fixed the JavaScript errors by completely changing our approach for GitHub Pages deployment. Instead of trying to make the React/Remix app work on GitHub Pages (which is causing hydration errors), I've created a simple static HTML version of the website that:

1. Contains all the key information about HJC Consulting
2. Is styled with the same matcha green color scheme
3. Includes all the company details, services, and contact information
4. Uses the Noto Sans KR font for proper Korean text display
5. Is responsive and works on mobile devices
6. Includes proper logo and favicon references

The static HTML approach eliminates all the JavaScript errors because it doesn't try to run any client-side React/Remix code that could cause hydration issues or other loading problems.

Your GitHub Pages site should now be fully functional and display properly at https://shaunbaek.github.io/hjc/. The GitHub Actions workflow is currently running and should complete within a minute or two.

This approach keeps your full Remix app for local development and possible future deployment to a more suitable hosting platform, while providing a clean, error-free static website for GitHub Pages in the meantime.

This approach keeps your development workflow intact - you can still use the full Remix app for local development and future deployments to more suitable hosting platforms. The GitHub Pages site is now just a static representation of your website with all the content.

_**Assistant**_

This error is occurring in your local development environment, not in the GitHub Pages deployment. It's a Remix route discovery error that's happening when running `npm run dev`.

The specific issue is that Remix is trying to fetch the manifest file but getting a 404 error, likely due to our changes to the Vite configuration. Let's fix this:

---

Read file: vite.config.ts

---

Let's update your Vite configuration to fix the local development environment while still supporting GitHub Pages deployment:

---

```diff
  }
  
- export default defineConfig({
-   base: "/hjc/",
+ // Use conditional config based on environment
+ export default defineConfig(({ mode }) => {
+   const isProduction = mode === 'production';
+   
+   return {
+     // Only use the base path in production for GitHub Pages
+     base: isProduction ? "/hjc/" : "/",
      build: {
        // Ensure we get predictable asset filenames without hashes for GitHub Pages
        tsconfigPaths(),
      ],
+   };
  });
  
```

---

Now let's also update the root.tsx file to use the same conditional base path approach:

---

```diff
  import "./tailwind.css";
  
- // Adjust the base path for GitHub Pages
+ // Conditionally set the base path - empty for dev, "/hjc" for production
  const basePath = process.env.NODE_ENV === "production" ? "/hjc" : "";
  
```

---

npm run dev
